text: For he remembered his holy promise, and Abraham his servant.
text_kjv: For he remembered his holy promise, and Abraham his servant.
text_niv: For he remembered his holy promisegiven to his servant Abraham.
text_esv: For he remembered his holy promise, and Abraham, his servant.
text_nlt: For he remembered his sacred promiseto his servant Abraham.
text_msg: All because he remembered his Covenant,his promise to Abraham, his servant.
text_nasb: For He remembered His holy word [With] Abraham His servant;
context: Psalm 105 is a historical psalm, recounting God's faithfulness to Israel from the time of Abraham through the Exodus. Understanding the historical and cultural background is crucial to grasping the significance of verse 42. Abraham, a Chaldean from Ur, was called by God to leave his homeland and journey to an unknown land, where he was promised descendants as numerous as the stars and that through him, all nations would be blessed (Genesis 12). This promise formed a covenant between God and Abraham, sealed with circumcision. The concept of covenants was deeply ingrained in ancient Near Eastern culture. Covenants were formal, binding agreements, often involving promises, obligations, and signs. The Abrahamic covenant was unique in that it was initiated and maintained solely by God's grace, a unilateral covenant. 'Servant,' in this context, indicates a position of loyalty, obedience, and dependence on God. Abraham's unwavering faith in God's promises, even when faced with seemingly impossible circumstances, is a recurring theme in the Old Testament. Remembering Abraham's role is crucial; he is the archetype of faith, and the promise to him laid the foundation for Israel's identity and destiny. The 'holy promise' itself is multifaceted, encompassing land, descendants, and blessing for all nations, ultimately pointing to the Messiah. The subsequent verses of Psalm 105 elaborate on how God delivered on His promise, despite generations of hardship and slavery in Egypt. The Exodus, therefore, is not just a liberation from bondage, but a fulfillment of the covenant made with Abraham centuries earlier.
meaning: Psalm 105:42 highlights the pivotal role of divine remembrance in the unfolding of salvation history. 'He remembered his holy promise' is not a statement suggesting God had forgotten, but rather a declaration that He acted upon His promise at the appointed time. Divine remembrance is an active, purposeful intervention into human affairs. The 'holy promise' refers to the covenant God made with Abraham, a covenant of grace based on God's sovereign choice, not on human merit. This covenant is 'holy' because it originates from God's sacred nature and purposes. The mention of 'Abraham his servant' emphasizes the importance of faith and obedience in receiving God's blessings. Abraham's faith was counted to him as righteousness (Genesis 15:6), making him a model for all who would believe. God's remembrance of His promise and of Abraham demonstrates His faithfulness and consistency. It underscores the immutability of God's character and the reliability of His word. The theological significance of this verse lies in its connection to the overarching narrative of redemption. God's faithfulness to Abraham paved the way for the nation of Israel, through whom the Messiah would eventually come. The Exodus, a direct consequence of God remembering His promise, prefigures the greater Exodus accomplished by Jesus Christ, who delivers humanity from the bondage of sin. Furthermore, this verse reaffirms the covenantal nature of God's relationship with humanity. God establishes covenants, makes promises, and remains faithful to those promises, even when humanity is unfaithful. The verse suggests that even today, God remembers His promises to those who are in Christ, fulfilling them in accordance with His perfect will and timing.
application: Psalm 105:42 provides several practical applications for modern believers. Firstly, it encourages us to trust in God's promises. Just as God remembered His promise to Abraham, He remembers His promises to us, promises of salvation, provision, and eternal life. When facing difficulties or uncertainties, we can draw strength from knowing that God is faithful to His word. Secondly, it calls us to be people of faith like Abraham. Abraham's faith was not passive; it was active and obedient. We are called to live out our faith in practical ways, trusting God even when we don't understand His plans. This means obeying His commands, serving others, and sharing the Gospel with boldness. Thirdly, it reminds us to be patient and persistent in prayer. God's timing is not always our timing. We may not see immediate results, but we can be confident that God is working behind the scenes to fulfill His purposes. Like Abraham, who waited many years for the promised son, we must persevere in prayer, trusting that God will answer in His own time and way. Fourthly, this verse teaches us the importance of remembering God's faithfulness in the past. By reflecting on God's past acts of deliverance and provision, we can strengthen our faith for the present and future. We can do this by reading the Bible, studying church history, and sharing testimonies of God's faithfulness in our own lives. Finally, Psalm 105:42 motivates us to be mindful of God's covenant with us through Jesus Christ. Through Christ's sacrifice, we have been included in the Abrahamic covenant, becoming heirs of God's promises. We should strive to live in accordance with this covenant, reflecting God's love and grace to the world around us. In essence, this verse calls us to a life of faith, obedience, and remembrance, trusting in God's unwavering faithfulness to His promises.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your faithfulness to Abraham and to all who put their trust in you. Thank you for remembering your holy promise and for sending your Son, Jesus Christ, to fulfill that promise. Lord, help us to be people of faith, like Abraham, trusting in your word even when we don't understand your ways. Give us patience to wait on your timing and perseverance to pray without ceasing. Remind us constantly of your past faithfulness so we can be encouraged when facing present challenges. Empower us to live out our covenant relationship with you, reflecting your love and grace to a world in need. Help us to remember the sacrifice of Jesus, that we may be mindful of your steadfast love. May we be faithful servants, just as Abraham was. In Jesus' name, we pray. Amen.

faqs.answer: No, it doesn't mean God forgot. 'Remembered' implies God acted upon his promise at the appropriate time. It signifies a purposeful and decisive intervention, showcasing his faithfulness and fulfilling his divine plan, not a lapse in memory.
faqs.question: Q1: What does it mean that God 'remembered' his promise? Does it imply He forgot it?

faqs.answer: Abraham is specifically mentioned because the promise referred to is the Abrahamic covenant. This covenant established a unique relationship and laid the foundation for God's plan of redemption for Israel and ultimately all nations through Jesus.
faqs.question: Q2: Why is Abraham specifically mentioned and not other figures like Noah or Moses?

faqs.answer: This verse shows God's long-term plan. The promise to Abraham included blessing all nations; this is fulfilled in Jesus, who offers salvation to everyone who believes, connecting the Old Testament covenant to the New Testament reality.
faqs.question: Q3: How does this verse relate to the New Testament and the coming of Jesus?

faqs.answer: Recognize God is faithful to His promises. When facing challenges, remember His character and trust that He will fulfill His word in your life. Be confident He is actively working for your good, even when you can't see it.
faqs.question: Q4: How can I apply the concept of God 'remembering' to my everyday life?

faqs.answer: Calling Abraham 'servant' highlights his role of loyalty, obedience, and dependence on God. He exemplified the kind of faith that trusts God's commands and is willing to follow where God leads, regardless of the circumstances.
